questions.text: The graph shows the growth of different tissues at various ages as a percentage of size at age 20. Identify the correct match.
questions.solution:
• The body and most visceral organs (c) follow a steady growth pattern from birth to adulthood, reaching their full size by around age 20. These organs include the heart, lungs, liver, and kidneys, which develop gradually, paralleling overall body growth.
  • Lymphoid tissue (a) experiences rapid growth during childhood, peaking around adolescence before declining. This includes tissues like the thymus and lymph nodes, crucial for immune function during early life.
  • The brain and head (b) show early rapid growth, with most of the growth occurring before age 6. By adolescence, the brain reaches about 90% of its adult size, showing minimal changes after this period.
  • Reproductive organs (d) grow significantly during puberty, undergoing a surge in size and function during adolescence due to hormonal changes, reaching maturity around adulthood.

Why not others:

  • a is for lymphoid tissue, which grows early and declines, not for the head.
  • b corresponds to brain and head, with early rapid growth, unlike reproductive organs.
  • d refers to reproductive organs, which grow later in life, not the brain.

Key Takeaways:

Different tissues grow at distinct rates: brain and head develop early, visceral organs grow steadily, lymphoid tissue peaks in childhood, and reproductive organs develop rapidly during puberty.

Increased risk of heart disease

There is heat intolerance

Constipation may occur

questions.text: A 35-year-old female came to the hospital with complaints of lethargy, weight gain and increased sleep. On investigation TSH value was much higher than normal with a low free T3 and T4. Which of the following statement is incorrect with respect to the given case?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with symptoms of hypothyroidism, indicated by high TSH and low free T3 and T4 levels. This condition can lead to various physiological changes.
  • A (Increased risk of heart disease): Correct, as low T3 levels increase cholesterol levels, heightening the risk of atherosclerosis and heart disease.
  • B (There is heat intolerance): Incorrect, because hypothyroidism typically leads to cold intolerance due to decreased metabolic heat production from low T3 levels.
  • C (Constipation may occur): Correct, as low T3 reduces gastrointestinal motility, leading to constipation.
  • D (Myxedema is seen): Correct, since hypothyroidism leads to the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans (GAGs), causing myxedema.

Why Not Others

  • A: High cholesterol levels from low T3 increase heart disease risk.
  • C: Low T3 causes decreased gut motility, contributing to constipation.
  • D: Low T3 leads to GAG accumulation, resulting in myxedema.

Key Takeaways

  • Correct answer: Option B is incorrect; patients with hypothyroidism experience cold intolerance, not heat intolerance.
  • Hypothyroidism results in various symptoms like lethargy, weight gain, constipation, and myxedema due to decreased levels of T3 and T4.Where as hyperthyroidism results in weight loss,diarrhea and heat intolerance.

choices.text: Less iodide through this symporter increases T3 and T4

questions.text: Choose incorrect statement regarding the symporter labelled as (a) in the diagram:
questions.solution:
The symporter labeled as (a) is the Sodium Iodide Symporter (NIS), which plays a crucial role in thyroid physiology.
The basolateral membranes of thyrocytes facing the capillaries contain a symporter that transports two Na+ ions and one I– ion into the cell with each cycle. It achieves I- concentration 20-40 times greater than plasma.

  • A (Less iodide through this symporter decreases T3 and T4): Incorrect, as decreased iodide transport through NIS actually leads to reduced T3 and T4 production due to insufficient iodide for hormone synthesis.
  • B (Type of secondary active transport): Correct, as NIS operates via secondary active transport, using the sodium gradient.
  • C (Function is iodide trapping): Correct, NIS actively transports iodide into thyroid follicular cells, effectively trapping it for thyroid hormone synthesis.
  • D (Present also in mammary gland): Correct, NIS is found in other tissues such as the salivary glands, mammary glands, and placenta.

Why Not Others

  • B: NIS is indeed a secondary active transporter that utilizes sodium gradients.
  • C: The primary function of NIS is to trap iodide for thyroid hormone production.
  • D: NIS is present in several tissues, including the mammary gland.

Key Takeaways

Correct answer: Option A is incorrect; less iodide transport through NIS decreases T3 and T4 production due to insufficient iodide.

NIS is crucial for iodide trapping and is a type of secondary active transport present in various tissues, supporting overall thyroid hormone synthesis.

questions.text: A child is suffering from goitre and sensorineural hearing loss. He is diagnosed to be the case of Pendred syndrome. This syndrome occurs due to defect in which of the following transporter?
questions.solution:
• Pendred syndrome is caused by a defect in the iodide-chloride antiporter, also known as Pendrin. Occurs due to mutation in SLC26A4 gene mutation on chromosome 7.
  • This defect leads to:
    • Goitre: due to impaired iodide transport into the thyroid gland, resulting in insufficient iodide for thyroid hormone synthesis.
    • Sensorineural hearing loss: associated with defects in the inner ear due to the malfunction of Pendrin, which is involved in ion transport in the cochlea.

Triad of pendred syndrome: congenital sensorineural hearing loss,goitre,impaired ioidide organification.

Why Not Others

  • A (Sodium Iodide Symporter): This transporter is essential for iodide uptake in the thyroid but is not the defect in Pendred syndrome.
  • C (Sodium potassium pump): This pump maintains membrane potential and is not directly related to iodide transport or Pendred syndrome.
  • D (Sodium chloride hydride cotransporter): This transporter is not involved in Pendred syndrome.

Key Takeaways

  • Correct answer: Option B, the iodide-chloride antiporter (Pendrin) is defective in Pendred syndrome, causing goitre and sensorineural hearing loss.
  • The syndrome highlights the critical role of Pendrin in both thyroid function and auditory health.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male came to the hospital with frontal bossing, prognathism, increase hand and foot size and increased heel pad thickness. The patient is diagnosed as the case of Acromegaly. Which of the following is correct about the treatment of it?
questions.solution:
• Acromegalyis caused by excess growth hormone, often due to a pituitary adenoma. It is seen after puberty producing enlargement of acral bones.
  • Characteristic features
  • Protrusion of supraorbital ridges.
  • Thickening of lips.
  • Thickening & wrinkle formation of forehead.
  • Protrusion of lower jaw - Prognathism.
  • Enlargement of hands & feet.
  • Frequent change of shoes.
  • Bowing of spine called as kyphosis.
  • Bulldog scalp
  • Treatment options include:
    • Trans-sphenoidal resection of microadenoma: This surgical approach is aimed at removing the tumour causing excess growth hormone secretion.
    • Ocreotide: A somatostatin analogue that inhibits growth hormone release from the pituitary gland.
    • Pegvisomant: A growth hormone receptor antagonist that blocks the action of growth hormone.

Why Not Others

  • A (Trans-sphenoidal resection of microadenoma): This is a valid treatment but not the only one.
  • B (Octreotide): This is also a correct treatment but does not encompass all options.
  • C (Pegvisomant): This option alone is a correct treatment but does not include others.

Key Takeaways

  • Correct answer: Option D, all of the following treatments are valid for acromegaly: surgery, Octreotide and Pegvisomant.
  • A multidisciplinary approach, combining surgical and pharmacological treatments, is essential for managing acromegaly effectively.

questions.text: A child came to the hospital whose plasma growth hormone concentration is normal but still he is dwarf. He is diagnosed as a case of Laron dwarfism. It occurs because their growth hormone receptors are unresponsive because of loss of mutations. Growth hormone acts on which receptor?
questions.solution:
• Laron dwarfism(growth hormone insensitivity syndrome) occurs due to mutations in growth hormone receptors, leading to unresponsiveness despite normal or elevated growth hormone levels.
  • Key points:
    • Plasma IGF-I: Levels are low due to the lack of response to growth hormone.
    • IGFBP-3: Insulin-like growth factor-binding protein 3, also decreased as it is growth hormone-dependent.
    • Treatment: Mecasermin (recombinant IGF-1) can help manage symptoms.

Why Not Others

  • A (G-protein coupled receptor): Growth hormone does not primarily act through this receptor type.
  • B (Nuclear receptor): Growth hormone action does not involve nuclear receptors directly.
  • D (Ion channel receptor): This type of receptor is not involved in growth hormone signalling.

Key Takeaways

  • Correct answer: Option C, growth hormone acts on the cytokine receptor.
  • The JAK-STAT pathway is activated upon growth hormone receptor binding, leading to downstream effects on growth and metabolism.

questions.text: Choose the correct match - levels of hormones since birth to 20 years of age:
questions.solution:
• The levels of hormones change significantly from birth to 20 years of age, with specific patterns for each hormone type.
  • Key points:
    • Thyroid hormones: Influence rapid growth in infancy and taper off after early childhood.
    • Growth hormone: Remains important throughout childhood and peaks during puberty.
    • Androgens and estrogens: Increase during puberty, contributing to the growth spurt. (8 t o16 years of age)

Why Not Others

  • A ('a' represents the Growth hormone): Incorrect, as 'a' corresponds to thyroid hormones. Thyroid hormone level is high during initial growth period and brain development till 3-4 years of age. After that it gradually starts declining.
  • B ('b' represents Estrogen): Incorrect, 'b' corresponds to growth hormone. The level of growth hormone is high during the growth phase from birth to around 16-17 years of age. (Infancy, child hood, adolescence)
  • C ('c' represents the Thyroid hormone): Incorrect, 'c' corresponds to androgens.

Key Takeaways

  • Correct answer: Option D, 'c' represents the androgens.
  • Hormones play a crucial role in growth and development, particularly during periods of rapid growth such as infancy and puberty.

questions.text: A person suffered from head trauma due to accident due to which the pituitary stalk has been affected. Levels of all the hormone decreases except?
questions.solution:
• In a pituitary stalk lesion, hormone levels are affected differently due to the regulatory mechanisms in place.
  • Pituitary stalk connects the hypothalamus to the anterior pituitary gland.
  • Key points:
    • Prolactin: Inhibition is primarily mediated by dopamine (prolactin inhibitory factor); thus, in the absence of inhibitory signals (due to stalk damage), prolactin levels increase.
    • Other hormones(TSH, FSH, ACTH): These hormones rely on stimulatory control, which decreases with stalk damage, leading to lower levels.

Why Not Others

  • A (TSH): Decreased due to lack of stimulation from the hypothalamus by thyrotropin releasing hormone.
  • C (FSH): Decreased as it requires hypothalamic hormones (gonadotropin releasing hormones)for regulation.
  • D (ACTH): Decreased since its secretion is stimulated by corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) from the hypothalamus.

Key Takeaways

  • Correct answer: Option B, Prolactin.
  • In pituitary stalk lesions, most hormones decrease, but prolactin levels can increase due to loss of inhibitory control from dopamine.

choices.text: Short limbs with a normal trunk

questions.text: A child came to the orthopaedic department with frontal bossing of skull, brachydactyly, saddle nose and proximal limb shortening. He was diagnosed as the case of achondroplasia. Which of the following is incorrect regarding achondroplasia?
questions.solution:
• Achondroplasia:
    • Key points:
      • Most common form of dwarfism: True, it is indeed the most prevalent type.
      • Short limbs with a normal trunk: Characteristic feature of achondroplasia.
      • FGFR3 gene mutation: It is caused by a mutation in the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 gene.

Why Not Others:

  • A (Most common form of dwarfism): Correct, as achondroplasia is indeed the most common form.
  • C (Short limbs with a normal trunk): True; this is a defining feature of the condition.
  • D (FGFR3 gene mutation): Correct, as this mutation is responsible for the disorder.

Key Takeaways:

  • Correct answer: Option B, Autosomal recessive condition.
  • Achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant condition, not recessive, characterized by specific skeletal features including short limbs and a normal trunk due to an FGFR3 gene mutation.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presented with weight loss, heat intolerance and irritability. She complaints that even after eating enough she is losing her weight. On investigation, her basal metabolic rate was very high. This disorder might be due to hypersecretion of which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Hyperthyroidism:
    • Key points:
      • Symptoms: Characterized by weight loss, heat intolerance, irritability, increased appetite (hyperphagia), and a high basal metabolic rate (BMR).
      • Causes: Most commonly due to hypersecretion of thyroxine (T4).
      • Graves Disease: An autoimmune condition leading to excessive T4 and T3 production, resulting in low plasma TSH levels due to negative feedback.

Why Not Others:

  • A (Cortisol): Excess cortisol typically causes Cushing's syndrome, characterized by weight gain and other symptoms, not weight loss.
  • B (Growth hormone): Hypersecretion can lead to conditions like acromegaly, primarily affecting growth and metabolism, not directly causing hyperthyroid symptoms.
  • D (Aldosterone): High levels lead to Conn's syndrome, causing hypertension and electrolyte imbalances but not hyperthyroid symptoms.

Key Takeaways:

  • Correct answer: Option C, Thyroxine.
  • The disorder is due to hypersecretion of thyroxine, causing symptoms like weight loss, heat intolerance, and an elevated basal metabolic rate. The most common cause is Graves disease, an autoimmune hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: A woman suffered an episode of shock due to postpartum haemorrhage and there is subsequent development of postpartum necrosis. She is diagnosed as a case of sheehans syndrome. Which of the feature is not seen?
questions.solution:
• Sheehan's Syndrome:
    • Key points:
      • Results from postpartum pituitary necrosis due to significant blood loss during or after childbirth.
      • Leads to hypopituitarism, affecting the production of various hormones, including those involved in lactation and reproductive function.
      • Common symptoms include lactational failure, hypoglycemia, and hypogonadism due to reduced hormone levels.

Why Not Others

  • A (Hyperthyroidism): Not a feature of Sheehan's syndrome; in fact, pituitary insufficiency can lead to hypothyroidism due to low TSH levels.
  • B (Lactational failure): Commonly seen due to low prolactin levels from pituitary damage.
  • C (Hypoglycemia): Can occur due to insufficient levels of growth hormone and cortisol, which regulate glucose metabolism.
  • D (Hypogonadism): Results from decreased production of gonadotropins (LH and FSH) due to pituitary damage.

Key Takeaways

  • Correct answer: Option A, Hyperthyroidism.
  • Sheehan's syndrome leads to hypopituitarism resulting in lactational failure, hypoglycemia, and hypogonadism, but hyperthyroidism is not seen due to pituitary dysfunction.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with weight loss, muscular weakness, and hyperpigmentation of skin, dehydration and hypotension. He was diagnosed as a case of Addison's disease. Hyperpigmentation of skin in this patient is mainly due to?
questions.solution:
• Addison's Disease:
    • Key points:
      • Characterized by adrenal insufficiency, leading to decreased production of glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids, and sex steroids.
      • Symptoms include weight loss, muscular weakness, hyperpigmentation, dehydration, and hypotension.

Why Not Others

  • A (MSH): While MSH (melanocyte-stimulating hormone) does stimulate pigmentation, in Addison's disease, the primary source of increased pigmentation is ACTH.
  • C (FSH): Follicle-stimulating hormone is involved in reproductive processes and does not contribute to skin pigmentation.
  • D (LH): Luteinizing hormone, like FSH, is primarily related to reproductive functions and does not influence skin pigmentation.

Key Takeaways

  • Correct answer: Option B, ACTH.
  • Hyperpigmentation in Addison's disease is due to excess ACTH, which stimulates melanocyte activity, leading to increased skin pigmentation.

questions.text:
Choose whether sentences are T-True or F-false
1. Thyroglobulin is made up of 124 tyrosines
2. Thyroglobulin is a protein similar to nature as Erythropoietin
3. Thyroglobulin has molecular weight 660,000 Dalton
questions.solution:
• Composition:
    • Tyrosine Residues: Thyroglobulin is made up of 123 tyrosines(not 124).
  • Nature:
    • Glycoprotein: It is a glycoprotein, similar to erythropoietin.
  • Molecular Weight:
    • 660,000 Dalton: Thyroglobulin has a molecular weight of 660 kDa.

True/False Statements

  • F: Thyroglobulin is made up of 123 tyrosines, not 124. (False)
  • T: Thyroglobulin is a glycoprotein, similar to erythropoietin. (True)
  • T: Thyroglobulin has a molecular weight of 660 kDa. (True)

B: It is the correct option

A (3rd statement is true),

C (1st statement is false and 3rd statement is true)

D (1st statement is false, 2nd statement is true and 3rd statement is true)

A, C, D are Incorrect options

Key takeaways:

FTT, as thyroglobulin has 123 tyrosines, is a glycoprotein like erythropoietin, and has a molecular weight of 660,000 Dalton.

choices.text: Hypothyroidism due to primary thyroid gland abnormality
Hypothyroidism due to abnormality of hypothalamus

questions.text: A young woman has puffy skin, her hair is coarse and sparse, dry and yellowish skin, and she has poor memory. The plasma TSH is reduced. On administration of TRH, the TSH level increases. What is your most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Symptoms of Hypothyroidism: The patient exhibits classic signs such as puffy skin (myxedema), coarse hair, dry skin, and poor memory.

  • TSH Levels: The low plasma TSH indicates an issue with the hypothalamus or pituitary.
  • TRH Response: The increase in TSH after TRH administration suggests that the pituitary is functioning normally, supporting the diagnosis of hypothalamic dysfunction.

Why not other options :

Option A: Hypothyroidism Due to Primary Thyroid Gland Abnormality: In primary hypothyroidism, TSH levels would be elevated due to low thyroid hormone levels, not reduced as seen in this patient.

Option B: Thyroid Adenoma: This typically causes hyperthyroidism, resulting in elevated TSH levels, which contradicts the findings of low TSH in this case.

Option D: Hypothyroidism Due to Pituitary Abnormality: If there were a pituitary abnormality, TSH would be low, but TRH administration would not lead to an increase in TSH if the pituitary were dysfunctional; therefore, the hypothalamic issue is more likely.

Key takeaways :

The most probable diagnosis for the young woman with puffy skin, coarse hair, dry skin, poor memory, and reduced TSH levels that increase after TRH administration is hypothyroidism due to an abnormality of the hypothalamus.

choices.text: Intolerance to heat as the body produces lot of heat due to increased basal metabolic rate
Diarrhea due to increased motility of GI tract
Muscular weakness because of excess protein catabolism

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with heat intolerance and menstrual abnormalities. She has Increased heart rate, increased stroke volume, increased protein catabolism, and decreased Peripheral Vascular Resistance. The probable diagnosis is hyperthyroidism. All the statements are correct except:
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is hyperthyroidism.

  • Key Points:

Option A: Heat intolerance occurs because the body produces excess heat due to an increased basal metabolic rate (BMR).

Option B: Diarrhea is common due to increased gastrointestinal motility.

Option C: Muscular weakness is a result of excess protein catabolism.

Option D: Weight loss occurs in hyperthyroidism due to fat mobilization and increased metabolism, making option D incorrect.

  • Other Symptoms:

Nervousness, hyperphagia, increased pulse pressure, fine tremor of fingers, warm and soft skin, sweating, and exophthalmos (protrusion of eyeballs).


Key takeaways:

Hyperthyroidism leads to heat intolerance, diarrhea, muscular weakness, and weight loss due to increased metabolism and protein catabolism.
